article:
E.A.T. (TV program)
=====================

E.A.T. is a Philippine television variety show that has been on the air since 1979. The show has undergone several changes in its format, hosts, and network affiliations over the years, but its core concept of entertainment, comedy, and public service has remained the same.

History
-------

### RPN (1979–1989)

E.A.T. first aired on July 30, 1979, on Radio Philippines Network (RPN) with a format that focused on entertainment, comedy, and news. The original hosts were Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon, collectively known as the "Tito, Vic, and Joey" (TVJ) trio. The show quickly gained popularity and became a staple of Philippine television.

### ABS-CBN (1989–1995)

In 1989, TVJ left RPN and moved to ABS-CBN, where they relaunched E.A.T. with a new format and new hosts. The show continued to thrive, with TVJ at the helm, until they left ABS-CBN in 1995.

### GMA Network (1995–2024)

In 1995, TVJ signed a new contract with GMA Network and relaunched E.A.T. once again. This time, the show was renamed "Eat Bulaga!" and was broadcast from the GMA Broadway Centrum in Quezon City. The show continued to gain popularity and became one of the longest-running and most-watched television shows in the Philippines.

### TVJ - TAPE Inc. conflict (2023–2024)

In 2023, a conflict arose between TVJ and TAPE Inc., the production company behind Eat Bulaga! TVJ, who had been hosting the show for over 40 years, wanted to take control of the show's production and management, while TAPE Inc. refused to give up its rights to the show. The conflict led to a series of lawsuits and counter-lawsuits between the parties.

#### E.A.T. and TAPE's Eat Bulaga!

As part of the conflict, TVJ launched a new show called E.A.T. on TV5, which was a revival of the original E.A.T. format from the 1970s. Meanwhile, TAPE Inc. continued to produce Eat Bulaga! without TVJ.

#### Eat Bulaga! trademark battle: TVJ emerges victorious

In a surprise move, TVJ won the trademark battle against TAPE Inc. for the rights to the Eat Bulaga! name. As a result, TAPE Inc. was forced to rename its show, which it did, calling it "Eat na Ta!".

### TV5 and RPTV (since 2024)

In 2024, TVJ signed a new contract with TV5 and relaunched E.A.T. once again. The show is now broadcast on TV5 and RPTV, with TVJ at the helm.

Hosts
-----

### Current host

The current host of E.A.T. is the Tito, Vic, and Joey (TVJ) trio, consisting of Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon.

### Former host

Former hosts of E.A.T. include Chiqui Hollman, Richie Reyes, and Helen Vela.

Segments
--------

### Current segments

#### Sugod Bahay, Mga Kapatid!

A segment where the hosts visit the homes of lucky viewers and give them prizes and surprises.

#### Gimme 5: Laro ng mga Henyo

A segment where contestants compete in a series of challenges to win prizes.

#### Peraphy

A segment where the hosts play a game of charades with celebrity guests.

#### Barangay Bulagaan

A segment where the hosts visit different barangays and play games with the residents.

#### Dear Eat Bulaga

A segment where viewers can write in and ask for advice or help from the hosts.

#### Eat Bulaga Olympics

A segment where the hosts compete in a series of physical challenges to win prizes.

#### Bawal! Judgmental Ka Ba?

A segment where the hosts play a game of wits with celebrity guests.

#### Concluded segments

#### Mr. Cutie: Boys Got Talent (2023–2024)

A segment where contestants competed to be crowned the most talented and handsome young man.

#### Babala! 'Wag Kayong Ganuuun... (2023–2024)

A segment where the hosts warned viewers about the dangers of certain behaviors or practices.

#### That's My Boyfriend (2024)

A segment where contestants competed to find their ideal boyfriend.

#### Rewind: The Comeback Stage (2024)

A segment where former winners of Eat Bulaga!'s talent competitions returned to compete again.

#### EB Centerstage

A segment where the hosts played a game of charades with celebrity guests.

#### Barangay Cinema: Child Star of the Year (2024)

A segment where young actors competed to be crowned the child star of the year.

Ratings
-------

E.A.T. has consistently been one of the highest-rated television shows in the Philippines, with ratings of over 30% in some episodes.

Controversies
------------

E.A.T. has been involved in several controversies over the years, including the TVJ-TAPE Inc. conflict and the trademark battle for the rights to the Eat Bulaga! name.

Spin-offs
---------

### Eat Na Ta!

A spin-off of Eat Bulaga! that was launched by TAPE Inc. after TVJ won the trademark battle.

### International versions

#### Eat Bulaga! Indonesia and The New Eat Bulaga! Indonesia

International versions of Eat Bulaga! that were launched in Indonesia.

#### Eat Bulaga! Myanmar

An international version of Eat Bulaga! that was launched in Myanmar.

Notes
-----

E.A.T. is one of the longest-running and most-watched television shows in the Philippines.

References
----------

External links
---------------

article:
Gilles de Rais

Gilles de Rais (1404-1440) was a French nobleman, military leader, and alleged serial killer. He is best known for his involvement in the Hundred Years' War and his subsequent trial and execution for the murder of numerous children. De Rais's life and crimes have been the subject of much speculation and debate, with some viewing him as a monster and others as a victim of circumstance.

# House of Retz

## Early life

Gilles de Rais was born in 1404 at the Château de Champtocé, in the province of Anjou, France. He was the son of Guy de Laval, Lord of Montjean, and Marie de Craon, heiress to the powerful Craon family. De Rais's family was part of the nobility, and he was raised with the expectation of becoming a military leader and defender of the faith.

## Matrimonial projects

In 1417, de Rais's parents arranged for him to marry Béatrice de Rohan, but the marriage was annulled due to her family's opposition. In 1420, he married Catherine de Thouars, with whom he had one daughter, Marie.

## Family disputes

De Rais's family was known for their disputes and conflicts with neighboring families. In 1425, his father was killed in a duel with a member of the rival family, the Chabot. De Rais's mother remarried, but her new husband, André de Lohéac, was also killed in a duel.

## Titles, estates and wealth

De Rais inherited a significant amount of wealth and property from his family, including the titles of Lord of Retz, Lord of Champtocé, and Lord of Machecoul. He also acquired the title of Marshal of France through his military service.

# Military career

## First hypothetical feat of arms

De Rais's military career began at a young age, and he is said to have fought in his first battle at the age of 16. However, there is no concrete evidence to support this claim.

## Franco-Breton alliance through the House of Valois-Anjou

In 1422, de Rais joined the army of Charles VII, King of France, and fought alongside him in the Hundred Years' War. He became a close ally of the king and was appointed as one of his chamberlains.

## Guerilla warfare against English garrisons on the borders of Maine

De Rais led a series of successful campaigns against the English garrisons on the borders of Maine, using guerrilla warfare tactics to great effect.

## Companion in arms with Joan of Arc

In 1429, de Rais met Joan of Arc, who had arrived in the French court to offer her services to the king. He became a close companion and supporter of hers, and fought alongside her in several battles.

## Civil wars between La Trémoille and Richemont's allies

In 1432, de Rais became embroiled in the civil wars between the factions of La Trémoille and Richemont. He fought on the side of La Trémoille, but was eventually reconciled with Richemont.

## Lifting of the siege of Lagny

In 1432, de Rais helped to lift the siege of Lagny, which had been besieged by the English. This was one of his most notable military victories.

## Reduction of military commitments

In the late 1430s, de Rais began to reduce his military commitments, preferring to focus on his personal life and interests.

# Squandering of heritage

De Rais was known for his extravagant lifestyle and his love of luxury. He spent vast sums of money on clothing, jewelry, and other lavish items, and was eventually forced to mortgage some of his properties to pay off his debts.

# Criminal life

## Occult involvement

De Rais became increasingly interested in the occult and alchemy, and was accused of making a pact with the devil. There is no concrete evidence to support this claim, but it is known that he was fascinated by the supernatural and the occult.

## Child murders

In 1432, de Rais was accused of murdering a large number of children, mostly boys, in the town of Machecoul. The exact number of victims is unknown, but it is estimated to be between 40 and 200.

## Act of force in Saint-Étienne-de-Mer-Morte

In 1438, de Rais was accused of using force to abduct a young boy from the town of Saint-Étienne-de-Mer-Morte. The boy was never seen again, and it is believed that he was murdered by de Rais.

## Ecclesiastical and secular investigations

In 1440, de Rais was investigated by both ecclesiastical and secular authorities, who accused him of a range of crimes including murder, sodomy, and heresy.

## Trial and execution

De Rais was put on trial in Nantes, and was found guilty of the charges against him. He was hanged on October 26, 1440, and his body was later burned.

# Question of guilt

## Doubts about the verdict in the Age of Enlightenment tradition

In the 18th century, some historians began to question the verdict against de Rais, suggesting that he may have been the victim of a miscarriage of justice.

## Occultist interpretations

Some occultists have interpreted de Rais's crimes as evidence of his involvement in a satanic cult.

## Georges Bataille's interpretations

The French philosopher Georges Bataille wrote extensively about de Rais, viewing him as a symbol of the destructive power of the human imagination.

## 1992 mock re-trial

In 1992, a mock re-trial of de Rais was held in France, which found him not guilty of the charges against him.

## Contemporary academic views

Most contemporary academics view de Rais as a serial killer who was responsible for the deaths of a large number of children. However, there is still some debate about the exact nature of his crimes and the motivations behind them.

# Fictional portraits

De Rais has been the subject of numerous fictional portraits, including plays, novels, and films. He is often depicted as a monstrous figure, driven by a lust for power and a desire for blood.

# Psychopathological interpretations

## Fin de siècle portrayals

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, de Rais was often portrayed as a decadent figure, driven by his desires and impulses.

## Classification as a serial killer

De Rais is often classified as a serial killer, due to the large number of victims he is believed to have murdered.

# Gilles de Rais and the Bluebeard myth

De Rais's crimes have been linked to the myth of Bluebeard, a figure from French folklore who is said to have murdered his wives.

# Relationship with Joan of Arc

De Rais's relationship with Joan of Arc has been the subject of much speculation and debate. Some have suggested that he was in love with her, while others have viewed their relationship as purely platonic.

2022 Badminton Asia Championships

The 2022 Badminton Asia Championships was the 40th edition of the Badminton Asia Championships, the premier badminton tournament in Asia. It was held from April 26 to May 1, 2022, in Manila, Philippines. The tournament was organized by the Badminton Asia Confederation (BAC) and was the first major badminton tournament to be held in the Philippines.

**Tournament**

### Venue

The 2022 Badminton Asia Championships was held at the Muntinlupa Sports Complex in Manila, Philippines. The complex has a seating capacity of 6,000 and features six badminton courts.

### Point distribution

The 2022 Badminton Asia Championships was a Grade 2 level tournament, which meant that the points earned by the players would be counted towards their world rankings.

### Prize money

The total prize money for the 2022 Badminton Asia Championships was $400,000, which was divided among the winners in the five categories: men's singles, women's singles, men's doubles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles.

**Medal summary**

article:
January 2023 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives Election

The January 2023 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election was held on January 3-7, 2023, to elect the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives for the 118th Congress. The election was necessary due to the change in party control of the House, with the Republicans gaining a majority.

Process and Conventions

In the United States House of Representatives, the Speaker is elected by the members of the House, typically from the party with the majority. The election is usually a formality, with the party's caucus nominating a candidate who is then elected by the full House. However, the January 2023 election was unusual due to the narrow Republican majority and internal party divisions.

The House of Representatives follows a set of conventions and rules for the election of the Speaker. The election is typically held on the first day of the new Congress, and the Speaker is elected by a majority of the votes cast. If no candidate receives a majority on the first ballot, subsequent ballots are held until a candidate is elected.

Democratic Nomination

### Candidates

#### Nominee

Hakeem Jeffries, the Chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, was the nominee of the Democratic Party for Speaker. Jeffries was the first African American to lead a party in Congress and had the support of the majority of the Democratic caucus.

#### Declined to Run

Several other Democrats were mentioned as potential candidates for Speaker, but they declined to run. These included Nancy Pelosi, the outgoing Speaker, and Steny Hoyer, the outgoing Majority Leader.

### Result

Jeffries was unanimously nominated by the Democratic caucus and received the support of all 212 Democratic members of the House.

Republican Nomination

### Candidates

#### Nominee

Kevin McCarthy, the House Minority Leader, was the nominee of the Republican Party for Speaker. McCarthy had the support of the majority of the Republican caucus, but faced opposition from a group of conservative Republicans.

#### Lost Nomination

Several other Republicans were mentioned as potential candidates for Speaker, but they lost the nomination to McCarthy. These included Steve Scalise, the House Minority Whip, and Jim Jordan, a prominent conservative Republican.

### Results

McCarthy was nominated by the Republican caucus, but received only 188 votes, short of the majority needed to be elected Speaker.

Election of the Speaker

### Background

The election of the Speaker was marked by divisions within the Republican Party. A group of conservative Republicans, known as the "Never Kevins," opposed McCarthy's nomination and refused to vote for him. This group was led by Matt Gaetz, Lauren Boebert, and Scott Perry.

### Candidates

The main candidates for Speaker were Hakeem Jeffries and Kevin McCarthy. However, several other Republicans were nominated by their colleagues during the election process.

### Summary

The election of the Speaker was a lengthy process that required 15 ballots over four days. McCarthy was eventually elected Speaker on the 15th ballot, after several concessions to the conservative Republicans.

### Ballots 1–3 (January 3)

On the first day of the election, three ballots were held. McCarthy received 203 votes on the first ballot, but this number decreased to 202 on the second ballot and 201 on the third ballot. Jeffries received 212 votes on all three ballots.

### Ballots 4–6 (January 4)

On the second day of the election, three ballots were held. McCarthy received 201 votes on all three ballots, while Jeffries received 212 votes.

### Ballots 7–11 (January 5)

On the third day of the election, five ballots were held. McCarthy received 201 votes on all five ballots, while Jeffries received 212 votes.

### Ballots 12–15 (January 6)

On the fourth day of the election, four ballots were held. McCarthy received 201 votes on the 12th ballot, but this number increased to 213 on the 15th ballot, after several concessions to the conservative Republicans. Jeffries received 212 votes on all four ballots.

### All Ballots: Votes Not Cast for Party Nominee

Several Republicans voted against their party's nominee during the election process. These included Matt Gaetz, Lauren Boebert, and Scott Perry.

### All Ballots: Summary of Votes

Impact

### Historical Context

The January 2023 Speaker election was the longest Speaker election since 1859, when it took 44 ballots to elect William Pennington as Speaker. The election was also marked by the first African American nominee for Speaker, Hakeem Jeffries.

### Consequences While There Was No Speaker

The delay in electing a Speaker had several consequences for the House of Representatives. The House was unable to swear in its members, and several committee hearings were postponed.

### C-SPAN Popularity

The Speaker election was widely covered by C-SPAN, which saw a significant increase in viewership during the election process. The network's coverage of the election was praised for its fairness and accuracy.

article:
Italian Renaissance Sculpture

Italian Renaissance sculpture is a style of sculpture that emerged in Italy during the Renaissance period, roughly spanning from the 14th to the 17th century. This period saw a resurgence in classical Greek and Roman styles, as well as the development of new techniques and forms. Italian Renaissance sculpture had a profound impact on the art world, influencing artists and styles for centuries to come.

# Periods

Italian Renaissance sculpture can be broadly divided into three periods: the Early Renaissance (1350-1450), the High Renaissance (1450-1520), and the Late Renaissance (1520-1600). Each period saw significant developments in style, technique, and theme.

# Materials

Italian Renaissance sculptors used a variety of materials, each with its unique characteristics and challenges.

## Stone

Marble was the most prized material for sculpture, due to its fine grain and ability to be carved into intricate details. Many famous sculptures, such as Michelangelo's David, were carved from marble. Other types of stone, such as limestone and travertine, were also used.

## Metal

Bronze was a popular material for sculpture, particularly for smaller works. It was valued for its durability and ability to be cast into intricate forms. Many bronze sculptures from the Renaissance period have survived to the present day.

## Wood

Wood was a common material for sculpture, particularly for smaller works and decorative objects. It was often used for relief carvings and figurines.

## Terracotta

Terracotta, a type of earthenware, was used for sculpture, particularly for smaller works and decorative objects. It was often glazed and used for figurines and reliefs.

## Other materials

Other materials, such as ivory, bone, and wax, were also used for sculpture. These materials were often used for smaller works and decorative objects.

## Coloured sculpture

Many Italian Renaissance sculptures were painted or gilded to add color and decoration. This practice, known as polychromy, was particularly popular for wooden sculptures.

# Settings

Italian Renaissance sculptures were often created for specific settings, such as churches, tombs, and civic spaces.

## Churches and tombs

Many sculptures were created for churches and tombs, often depicting saints, biblical figures, and other religious subjects. These sculptures were often large-scale and intricately carved.

## Civic pride

Sculptures were also created to promote civic pride and identity. Many cities and towns commissioned sculptures to adorn their public spaces and buildings.

### Fountains

Fountains were a popular type of sculpture, often featuring mythological figures and animals. They were used to decorate public spaces and provide a source of water.

## Portraits

Portrait sculpture was a popular genre, particularly for wealthy patrons. Many famous artists, such as Michelangelo and Donatello, created portrait sculptures.

### Equestrian statues

Equestrian statues, depicting riders on horseback, were a popular type of portrait sculpture. They were often used to commemorate famous leaders and military victories.

### Shoulder busts

Shoulder busts, depicting the head and shoulders of a subject, were a popular type of portrait sculpture. They were often used to commemorate famous individuals and leaders.

### Medals

Medals, small sculptures featuring a portrait or image on one side, were a popular type of portrait sculpture. They were often used to commemorate events and individuals.

## Small sculpture

Small sculptures, such as figurines and reliefs, were popular decorative objects. They were often used to adorn homes and public spaces.

# Workshops

Many Italian Renaissance sculptors worked in workshops, often with apprentices and assistants. These workshops were often family-run and passed down through generations.

## Women sculptors

While women sculptors were relatively rare during the Italian Renaissance, some notable female artists emerged during this period. One famous example is Properzia de' Rossi, who worked in Bologna during the 16th century.

# Guilds

Many Italian Renaissance sculptors belonged to guilds, which were organizations of craftsmen and artists. These guilds helped regulate the profession and provided training and support for members.

# Patrons

Italian Renaissance sculpture was often commissioned by wealthy patrons, such as the Medici family in Florence. These patrons played a significant role in shaping the development of sculpture during this period.

# Development of style

Italian Renaissance sculpture developed over several centuries, influenced by classical styles and techniques.

## To 1400

During the 14th century, Italian sculpture was heavily influenced by Byzantine and Gothic styles. However, with the emergence of humanism and classical studies, sculptors began to look to ancient Greek and Roman models for inspiration.

## From 1400

The 15th century saw a significant development in Italian Renaissance sculpture, particularly in Florence.

### Doors of the Florence Baptistery

The doors of the Florence Baptistery, created by Lorenzo Ghiberti, are a famous example of early Renaissance sculpture. The doors feature intricate reliefs and demonstrate a strong classical influence.

### Donatello

Donatello was a prominent sculptor of the early Renaissance, known for his innovative and expressive works. His sculptures often featured contrapposto, a pose where the weight-bearing leg is relaxed and the free leg is tensed.

### Middle of the century

By the middle of the 15th century, Italian Renaissance sculpture had developed a distinct style, characterized by naturalism, classical influences, and attention to detail.

### Lombardy

In Lombardy, a region in northern Italy, sculpture developed a distinct style, characterized by a focus on decorative and ornate details.

### Crisis of the 1490s

The 1490s saw a crisis in Italian Renaissance sculpture, as many artists were forced to flee their homes due to war and political instability. However, this period also saw the emergence of new styles and techniques.

## 16th century

The 16th century saw the rise of Mannerism and Late Renaissance sculpture.

### Michelangelo

Michelangelo was a prominent sculptor of the 16th century, known for his iconic works such as the Pietà and David. His sculptures often featured complex and dynamic poses.

### Mannerist and Late Renaissance sculpture

Mannerist sculpture, characterized by elongated forms and unnatural poses, emerged in the mid-16th century. Late Renaissance sculpture, characterized by a focus on naturalism and classical influences, emerged in the late 16th century.

### Giambologna

Giambologna was a prominent sculptor of the Late Renaissance, known for his elegant and refined works. His sculptures often featured complex and dynamic poses.

# Italians abroad

Many Italian Renaissance sculptors worked abroad, particularly in France and the Netherlands.

article:
History of Christianity

Christianity is one of the world's major religions, with a history spanning over 2,000 years. Its origins are rooted in the life and teachings of Jesus Christ, who preached a message of love, redemption, and salvation to the people of ancient Palestine. From its humble beginnings as a small Jewish sect, Christianity has grown into a global faith with billions of adherents, influencing art, culture, philosophy, and politics throughout history.

# Early Christianity

## Jewish background

Christianity emerged from within Judaism, and its early history is deeply connected to the Jewish people and their traditions. Jesus Christ, the founder of Christianity, was born into a Jewish family in Bethlehem, around 4 BCE. He was raised in Nazareth, in the province of Galilee, and later traveled to Jerusalem, where he preached and performed miracles. Jesus' teachings were rooted in Jewish scripture and tradition, but he also challenged certain aspects of Jewish law and practice, which ultimately led to his crucifixion by the Roman authorities.

## Apostolic Age (c. 30–100)

### Developing church structure

After Jesus' death and resurrection, his followers, known as the apostles, began to spread his teachings and establish communities of believers. The apostles, led by Peter and Paul, traveled throughout the Mediterranean world, preaching and baptizing new converts. As the number of believers grew, the apostles established a system of governance, with bishops, presbyters, and deacons, to oversee the various communities.

### Early growth

The early Christian church experienced rapid growth, particularly among the Jewish population. According to the New Testament, on the day of Pentecost, following Jesus' resurrection, over 3,000 people were baptized, marking the beginning of the Christian church. The church continued to grow, with converts coming from all walks of life, including Gentiles (non-Jews).

## Ante-Nicene period (100–312)

### Scripture

During this period, the Christian scriptures, including the Gospels and the Epistles, were written and circulated among the communities. The process of canonization, or the establishment of the authoritative texts, began, with the earliest collections of scripture dating back to the 2nd century.

### Early Christian art

Christian art emerged during this period, with symbols such as the cross, the fish, and the alpha and omega becoming common motifs. Early Christian art often incorporated elements of Jewish and pagan art, reflecting the diverse cultural influences of the Mediterranean world.

### Persecutions and legalization

The early Christian church faced numerous persecutions, particularly under the Roman Empire. Christians were often viewed as a threat to the established order and were subjected to torture, imprisonment, and execution. However, in 313 CE, the Edict of Milan, issued by Emperor Constantine, granted Christians freedom of worship, marking a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

## Spread of Christianity to c. 300 AD

### Inclusivity, women and exclusivity

Early Christianity was characterized by a sense of inclusivity, with women playing a significant role in the spread of the faith. Women such as Mary Magdalene and Phoebe were prominent leaders in the early church, and women's households often served as centers of Christian activity. However, as the church grew and became more institutionalized, women's roles became increasingly limited.

### Moral practices

Early Christians emphasized the importance of moral practices, such as charity, forgiveness, and humility. The church also developed a system of moral guidance, with the apostles and later bishops providing counsel on matters of ethics and behavior.

# Late antiquity (313–476)

## Conversion of Constantine

### Christianity and the state

In 312 CE, Emperor Constantine converted to Christianity, marking a significant turning point in the history of the faith. Constantine's conversion led to the establishment of Christianity as a state-sponsored religion, with the emperor providing financial support and protection to the church.

### Christianity and polytheism

As Christianity spread throughout the empire, it encountered numerous polytheistic cults and traditions. The early Christian church responded to these challenges by developing a theology of monotheism, emphasizing the exclusive worship of the one true God.

## Augustine's ethic toward Jews

Augustine of Hippo, a prominent early Christian theologian, developed a complex and often contradictory ethic toward Jews. While Augustine acknowledged the importance of Jewish scripture and tradition, he also viewed Jews as being in a state of spiritual blindness, requiring conversion to Christianity.

## Developing orthodoxy and heresy

As Christianity spread, various theological disputes and controversies emerged, leading to the development of orthodox and heretical positions. The early church councils, such as Nicaea (325 CE) and Constantinople (381 CE), played a crucial role in establishing the boundaries of orthodox doctrine.

## Church of the East

The Church of the East, also known as the Nestorian Church, emerged in the 5th century, particularly in the regions of Persia and India. This church developed a distinct theology and practice, often at odds with the Western Christian tradition.

## Hospitals

Early Christians established hospitals and other charitable institutions, providing care and support to the sick and the poor. These institutions played a significant role in the development of Western healthcare and social welfare.

## Art and literature

Christian art and literature flourished during this period, with the development of illuminated manuscripts, mosaics, and other forms of artistic expression.

## Spread and growth of Christianity

### Christianity in the Roman Africa province

Christianity spread rapidly throughout the Roman province of Africa, particularly in the cities of Carthage and Hippo. The church in Africa developed a distinct theology and practice, often influenced by local cultural and social conditions.

### German Europe, Britain and Ireland

Christianity was introduced to German Europe, Britain, and Ireland through the missionary activities of monks and clergy. The church in these regions developed a unique character, often shaped by local customs and traditions.

### Asia

Christianity spread to Asia, particularly through the trade routes and missionary activities of the Church of the East. The church in Asia developed a distinct theology and practice, often influenced by local cultural and social conditions.

# Early Middle Ages (476–842)

## Justinian I

Justinian I, the Byzantine emperor, played a significant role in the development of Christianity, particularly through his codification of Roman law and his support for the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople.

## Education

The early Middle Ages saw a decline in classical education, but the church continued to support learning and scholarship, particularly through the establishment of monastic schools.

## Law

The early Middle Ages saw the development of canon law, which governed the practices and institutions of the church.

## Monasticism

Monasticism emerged as a prominent form of Christian spirituality, with the establishment of monasteries and convents throughout Europe. Monasticism emphasized the importance of prayer, work, and community.

## Art

Christian art continued to develop during this period, with the emergence of new forms such as the icon and the illuminated manuscript.

## Papal supremacy

The papacy emerged as a dominant force in Western Christianity, with the pope claiming supreme authority over the church.

## Spread and growth of Christianity

Christianity continued to spread throughout Europe, particularly through the missionary activities of monks and clergy.

# High Middle Ages (842–1299)

## Christendom 842-1099

### Tenth and eleventh century reform

The 10th and 11th centuries saw a period of reform within the church, particularly through the efforts of monks and clergy who sought to purify the church of corruption and abuse.

### Investiture controversy (1078)

The investiture controversy emerged as a major crisis within the church, with the pope and the emperor disputing the right to appoint bishops.

### Toledo 1085

The city of Toledo was reconquered by Christian forces in 1085, marking a significant turning point in the history of Spain.

### First crusade (1095)

The First Crusade was launched in 1095, with Christian armies marching to recapture the Holy Land from Muslim forces.

### Learning and change

The High Middle Ages saw a period of significant learning and change, particularly through the emergence of universities and the rediscovery of classical texts.

### Scholasticism, Renaissance and science (1150-1200)

Scholasticism emerged as a dominant form of Christian theology, emphasizing the use of reason and dialectic. The High Middle Ages also saw the emergence of the Renaissance and the development of scientific inquiry.

### Universities

Universities emerged as centers of learning and intellectual inquiry, particularly in cities such as Paris and Oxford.

### Art, architecture and music

Christian art, architecture, and music continued to develop during this period, with the emergence of new forms such as the Gothic cathedral and the polyphonic motet.

## Political power, the church and the papacy

### Papacy

The papacy emerged as a dominant force in Western Christianity, with the pope claiming supreme authority over the church.

### Medieval Inquisition

The Medieval Inquisition emerged as a response to heresy and dissent within the church, with the establishment of tribunals and the use of torture and execution.

### Fourth crusade (1204)

The Fourth Crusade was launched in 1204, with Christian armies marching to recapture the Holy Land. However, the crusade ultimately failed, and the city of Constantinople was sacked.

## Spread and retraction of Christianity from the 800s

### Mesopotamia and Egypt

Christianity spread throughout Mesopotamia and Egypt, particularly through the missionary activities of the Church of the East.

### Scandinavia

Christianity was introduced to Scandinavia, particularly through the missionary activities of monks and clergy.

### Russia

Christianity was introduced to Russia, particularly through the missionary activities of the Byzantine Empire.

### Baltic and central Europe

Christianity spread throughout the Baltic and central Europe, particularly through the missionary activities of monks and clergy.

### The East (1054)

The Great Schism emerged in 1054, with the Eastern and Western churches dividing over issues of doctrine and authority.

### Northern crusades (1147–1316)

The Northern Crusades were launched in the 12th century, with Christian armies marching to convert the pagan peoples of northern Europe.

### Albigensian Crusade (1209 - 1229)

The Albigensian Crusade was launched in the 13th century, with Christian armies marching to suppress the Cathar heresy in southern France.

## Persecution of Jews

### Fourth Lateran Council (1215)

The Fourth Lateran Council was convened in 1215, with the church issuing a series of decrees against Jews, including the requirement that Jews wear distinctive clothing.

# Late Middle Ages and early Renaissance (c. 1300–1520)

## Avignon Papacy and the Western Schism

The Avignon Papacy emerged in the 14th century, with the pope residing in Avignon rather than Rome. The Western Schism emerged in the 15th century, with multiple claimants to the papacy.

## Criticism and reform

Criticism and reform emerged within the church, particularly through the efforts of theologians and clergy who sought to purify the church of corruption and abuse.

## Art

Christian art continued to develop during this period, with the emergence of new forms such as the International Gothic style.

## Byzantium and the Fall of Constantinople in 1453

The Byzantine Empire fell in 1453, with the city of Constantinople being conquered by the Ottoman Turks.

## Modern Inquisition

The Modern Inquisition emerged in the 15th century, with the establishment of tribunals and the use of torture and execution.

## Expulsion of Jews

Jews were expelled from various countries, including Spain and Portugal, in the 15th and 16th centuries.

# Early modernity (1500–1750)

## Reformation and response in Western Europe (1517–1700)

### Protestant Reformation

The Protestant Reformation emerged in the 16th century, with theologians such as Martin Luther and John Calvin challenging Catholic doctrine and practice.

### Counter-Reformation

The Counter-Reformation emerged in response to the Protestant Reformation, with the Catholic Church seeking to reform and revitalize itself.

### Internecine wars

Internecine wars emerged between Protestant and Catholic states, particularly in the 17th century.

### Witch trials

Witch trials emerged in the 16th and 17th centuries, with the execution of thousands of people accused of witchcraft.

### Modern concepts of tolerance

Modern concepts of tolerance emerged in the 17th and 18th centuries, particularly through the writings of philosophers such as John Locke.

## Eastern-Orthodox Churches

The Eastern-Orthodox Churches developed distinct traditions and practices, particularly in the 16th and 17th centuries.

## The Age of Enlightenment and the start of secularisation (17th-18th c.)

The Age of Enlightenment emerged in the 17th and 18th centuries, with philosophers such as René Descartes and Immanuel Kant challenging traditional Christian doctrine and practice.

## Art

Christian art continued to develop during this period, with the emergence of new forms such as the Baroque style.

## Colonialism and missions

### Asia

Christianity was introduced to Asia, particularly through the missionary activities of European powers.

# Late modernity (1750–1945)

## Biblical criticism, liberalism, fundamentalism

Biblical criticism emerged in the 18th and 19th centuries, with scholars challenging traditional Christian interpretations of the Bible. Liberalism and fundamentalism emerged as responses to biblical criticism.

## American religious revivals (1730–1850)

American religious revivals emerged in the 18th and 19th centuries, with the Second Great Awakening and the Third Great Awakening.

## Western slavery

Western slavery emerged in the 16th and 17th centuries, with the transatlantic slave trade.

## Protestant missions

Protestant missions emerged in the 19th century, with the establishment of missionary societies and the sending of missionaries to various parts of the world.

### Native American boarding schools

Native American boarding schools emerged in the 19th century, with the forced assimilation of Native American children into Western culture.

## Russian Orthodoxy

Russian Orthodoxy developed distinct traditions and practices, particularly in the 19th and 20th centuries.

## Christianity and Nazism

Christianity and Nazism intersected in the 20th century, with some Christians supporting the Nazi regime and others opposing it.

# After 1945

## A global religion

### Africa (19th–21st centuries)

Christianity spread throughout Africa, particularly through the missionary activities of European powers.

### Asia

Christianity continued to spread throughout Asia, particularly through the missionary activities of Western powers.

## Challenges

Christianity faced various challenges in the 20th and 21st centuries, including secularism, pluralism, and persecution.

## Diversity and commonality

Christianity exhibited diversity and commonality, with various traditions and practices emerging around the world.

## War

Christianity was often associated with war and violence, particularly in the 20th century.

## Particularizng Emancipation

### Missions

Christian missions continued to play a significant role in the spread of Christianity, particularly in the 20th and 21st centuries.

# See also

* List of Christian denominations
* Timeline of Christian missions
* Christianity and slavery

# Notes

This article uses the Gregorian calendar, which is the standard calendar used in most of the Western world.

# References

This article does not include citations or references. For a list of sources, see below.

# Sources

## Books & periodicals

* Brown, Peter. The Rise of Christendom. Oxford: Blackwell, 1996.
* Chadwick, Henry. The Early Church. London: Penguin, 1967.
* Cross, F.L. and E.A. Livingstone. The Oxford Dictionary of the Christian Church. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005.
* Pelikan, Jaroslav. The Christian Tradition: A History of the Development of Doctrine. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1971.

## Encyclopedia & web sources

* Catholic Encyclopedia. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1913.
* Encyclopedia Britannica. Chicago: Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., 2019.
* World Christian Encyclopedia. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001.

2023 Giro d'Italia

The 2023 Giro d'Italia is the 106th edition of the Giro d'Italia, one of the three Grand Tours in the UCI World Tour calendar. The event took place from May 6 to May 28, 2023, and covered a total distance of 3,448 kilometers. The Giro d'Italia is one of the most prestigious cycling events in the world, and this year's edition promises to be an exciting and challenging ride for the participating teams and riders.

# Teams

A total of 22 teams participated in the 2023 Giro d'Italia, including 18 UCI WorldTeams and 4 UCI ProTeams. The teams were:

* AG2R Citroën Team
* Alpecin-Deceuninck
* Astana Qazaqstan Team
* Bahrain - Victorious
* Bora - Hansgrohe
* Cofidis
* EF Education - EasyPost
* Eolo-Kometa Cycling Team
* Groupama - FDJ
* INEOS Grenadiers
* Intermarché - Circus - Wanty
* Israel - Premier Tech
* Jumbo-Visma
* Movistar Team
* Quick-Step Alpha Vinyl Team
* Team BikeExchange - Jayco
* Team DSM
* Team TotalEnergies
* Trek - Segafredo
* UAE Team Emirates

# Pre-race favourites

The pre-race favourites for the 2023 Giro d'Italia included several top-class riders, including:

* Remco Evenepoel (Soudal - Quick-Step)
* Primož Roglič (Jumbo-Visma)
* Geraint Thomas (INEOS Grenadiers)
* Tao Geoghegan Hart (INEOS Grenadiers)
* Richard Carapaz (EF Education - EasyPost)
* João Almeida (UAE Team Emirates)
* Mikel Landa (Bahrain - Victorious)
* Giulio Ciccone (Trek - Segafredo)

These riders had all shown impressive form in the lead-up to the Giro, and were expected to be among the main contenders for the general classification.

# Route and stages

The 2023 Giro d'Italia consisted of 21 stages, covering a total distance of 3,448 kilometers. The route took the riders through several regions of Italy, including the north, center, and south. The stages were:

* Stage 1: Fossacesia - Ortona (203km)
* Stage 2: Teramo - San Salvo (202km)

* Stage 12: Bra - Rivoli (186km)
* Stage 13: Borgofranco d'Ivrea - Crissolo (149km)
* Stage 14: Sierre - Cassano Magnago (194km)
* Stage 15: Seregno - Bergamo (195km)
* Stage 16: Sabbio Chiese - Monte Bondone (203km)
* Stage 17: Pergine Valsugana - Caorle (195km)
* Stage 18: Oderzo - Treviso (152km)
* Stage 19: Treviso - San Martino di Castrozza (183km)
* Stage 20: Tarvisio - Monte Lussari (18km)
* Stage 21: Roma - Roma (135km)

# Classification leadership

Throughout the Giro d'Italia, there were several classification leaders, including:

* General classification: Remco Evenepoel (Soudal - Quick-Step)
* Points classification: Jonathan Milan (Bahrain - Victorious)
* Mountains classification: Thibaut Pinot (Groupama - FDJ)
* Young rider classification: Remco Evenepoel (Soudal - Quick-Step)

## General classification

The final general classification standings were:

1. Remco Evenepoel (Soudal - Quick-Step) - 86h 27' 28"
2. Geraint Thomas (INEOS Grenadiers) - + 1' 18"
3. Primož Roglič (Jumbo-Visma) - + 1' 43"
4. Tao Geoghegan Hart (INEOS Grenadiers) - + 2' 06"
5. João Almeida (UAE Team Emirates) - + 2' 33"

# Notes

* The 2023 Giro d'Italia was the first Grand Tour to be held since the COVID-19 pandemic.

* The Giro d'Italia was broadcast in over 180 countries around the world.

article:
Mariupol
==========

Mariupol is a city in the Donetsk Oblast of Ukraine, located on the north coast of the Sea of Azov. With a population of approximately 449,000 people, it is one of the largest cities in the region and serves as a major industrial and cultural center. Mariupol has a rich and complex history, having been part of various empires and states throughout the centuries.

History
-------

### Ancient history

The area around Mariupol has been inhabited since ancient times, with archaeological findings indicating the presence of human settlements dating back to the Stone Age. The city's strategic location on the Sea of Azov made it an attractive spot for trade and commerce, and it was an important center for the ancient Greeks and Romans.

### Crimean Khanate

In the 13th century, the area was conquered by the Golden Horde, a Mongol khanate that ruled over much of Eastern Europe and Central Asia. Later, it became part of the Crimean Khanate, a Turkic state that existed from the 15th to the 18th centuries. During this period, the city was known as Kalmius.

### Cossack period

In the 16th century, the area was settled by Cossacks, a group of semi-autonomous warriors who played a significant role in the history of Ukraine. The Cossacks established a number of settlements in the region, including Mariupol, which became an important center for trade and commerce.

### Russian Empire and Soviet Union

In 1779, the city was annexed by the Russian Empire, and it became an important center for industry and trade. During the 19th and 20th centuries, Mariupol underwent significant industrialization and urbanization, with the development of steel production, shipbuilding, and other industries. After the Russian Revolution, Mariupol became part of the Soviet Union, and it continued to play an important role in the country's economy.

### World War II

During World War II, Mariupol was occupied by German forces, and the city suffered significant damage. The city was liberated by Soviet forces in 1943, and it played an important role in the country's post-war reconstruction efforts.

### Russo-Ukrainian War

#### War in Donbas and economic downturn

In 2014, Mariupol became embroiled in the Russo-Ukrainian War, as pro-Russian separatists seized control of much of the Donetsk Oblast. The city was the site of significant fighting, and it suffered significant economic damage. In 2015, the Ukrainian government launched a major counter-offensive, and the city was recaptured.

#### 2022 Russian siege and subsequent occupation

In February 2022, Russian forces launched a major invasion of Ukraine, and Mariupol was one of the first cities to be besieged. The city was subjected to intense bombardment, and it suffered significant damage. In March 2022, Russian forces captured the city, and it has remained under Russian occupation ever since.

Geography
---------

### Climate

Mariupol has a humid continental climate, with cold winters and warm summers. The city is located on the coast of the Sea of Azov, and its climate is influenced by the sea. The average temperature in January, the coldest month, is around -2°C (28°F), while the average temperature in July, the warmest month, is around 23°C (73°F).

### Ecology

The area around Mariupol is home to a number of natural reserves and protected areas, including the Mariupol Bay, which is an important habitat for migratory birds. The city is also home to a number of parks and gardens, including the Mariupol City Garden, which is a popular spot for recreation and relaxation.

Governance
----------

### City administration and local politics

Mariupol is governed by a city council, which is composed of 50 deputies who are elected by the city's residents. The city is also home to a number of local political parties and organizations, including the Mariupol City Organization of the All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland" and the Mariupol City Organization of the Party of Regions.

### Administrative division

Mariupol is divided into four administrative districts, including the Kalmiuskyi District, the Central District, the Prymorskyi District, and the Livoberezhnyi District.

### Coat of arms

Gubernatorial elections

2022 Women's FIH Hockey Junior World Cup

The 2022 Women's FIH Hockey Junior World Cup was the 9th edition of the Women's FIH Hockey Junior World Cup, the biennial international women's field hockey tournament for junior-level national teams organized by the International Hockey Federation (FIH). It was held in Potchefstroom, South Africa from April 1 to 12, 2022.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the tournament involved the top 5 teams from the 2019 Junior Africa Cup for Nations, the top 4 teams from the 2021 Junior Asia Cup, the top 4 teams from the 2021 Junior Europe Championship, the top 2 teams from the 2021 Junior Oceania Cup, and the top 2 teams from the 2021 Junior Pan American Championship. article:
Jailer (2023 Tamil film)
======================

Jailer is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action comedy film written and directed by Nelson Dilipkumar. The film stars Rajinikanth, Tamannaah, Ramya Krishnan, and Yogi Babu in lead roles. Produced by Kalanithi Maran under the banner of Sun Pictures, Jailer was released theatrically on 10 August 2023.

Plot
-----

The film revolves around Muthuvel Pandian (Rajinikanth), a senior jailer who is tasked with investigating a mysterious occurrence within the prison premises. As he delves deeper into the case, he uncovers a web of corruption and deceit that threatens the very fabric of the prison system. Along the way, he must confront his own demons and team up with a group of unlikely allies to bring the perpetrators to justice.

Cast
-----

* Rajinikanth as Muthuvel Pandian
* Tamannaah as Kannamma
* Ramya Krishnan as Kaaliammal
* Yogi Babu as Pazhani
* Vasanth Ravi as Aashiq
* Redin Kingsley as Raja
* G. Marimuthu as Veluchamy
* Sathish as Sathish
* Mohan Raja as Guru

Production
------------

### Development

Nelson Dilipkumar began working on the script for Jailer in 2020, shortly after the release of his film Doctor. He initially planned to cast Sivakarthikeyan in the lead role, but later decided to approach Rajinikanth. The two met in November 2020 to discuss the project, and Rajinikanth agreed to come on board.

### Pre-production

Pre-production work on Jailer began in December 2020, with Nelson Dilipkumar and his team conducting extensive research on the prison system. They visited several prisons in Tamil Nadu and consulted with former prisoners and jail officials to get a better understanding of the subject matter.

### Casting

Rajinikanth was the first actor to be cast in the film, followed by Tamannaah and Ramya Krishnan. Yogi Babu was brought on board to play a comic relief role, while Vasanth Ravi and Redin Kingsley were cast in supporting roles.

### Filming

Principal photography for Jailer began on 10 August 2022 and lasted for approximately six months. The film was shot on location in Chennai, Hyderabad, and Ooty, with a few scenes being filmed in a specially constructed prison set.

### Post-production

Post-production work on Jailer began in February 2023, with Nelson Dilipkumar working closely with editor R. Nirmal to edit the film. The film's score was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, who also worked on the film's sound design.

Music
------

The soundtrack for Jailer was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, with lyrics written by Vivek, Arivu, and Arunraja Kamaraj. The soundtrack features six songs, including the hit single "Kaavaalaa".

Marketing
----------

The marketing campaign for Jailer began in May 2023, with the release of a teaser trailer that showcased Rajinikanth's character. The trailer received a massive response from fans, with many praising Rajinikanth's performance.

Release
--------

### Theatrical

Jailer was released theatrically on 10 August 2023, coinciding with the Independence Day weekend. The film was released in over 1,000 screens in Tamil Nadu, with a few screens showing the film with English subtitles.

### Screenings and statistics

According to reports, Jailer grossed over ₹100 crore in its opening weekend, with many screens showing the film to packed houses. The film received a massive response from fans, with many praising Rajinikanth's performance.

### Distribution

Jailer was distributed by Red Giant Movies in Tamil Nadu, with the film being distributed by UV Creations in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

### Home media

The film's digital rights were acquired by Netflix, with the film being made available on the platform on 15 September 2023.

### Controversies

Jailer was involved in a controversy when a group of activists alleged that the film portrayed the prison system in a negative light. The controversy died down after Nelson Dilipkumar clarified that the film was a work of fiction and not meant to be taken seriously.

Reception
----------

### Critical response

Jailer received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising Rajinikanth's performance. The film's action sequences and comedy were also praised, with many calling the film a "mass entertainer".

### Box office

Jailer was a commercial success, grossing over ₹250 crore worldwide. The film's success was attributed to Rajinikanth's massive fan base, as well as the film's well-crafted script and direction.

Sequel
--------

In an interview, Nelson Dilipkumar stated that he was open to making a sequel to Jailer, but only if he could come up with a script that was better than the original.

Documentary series
-----------------

A documentary series on the making of Jailer was released on Netflix in September 2023. The series, titled "The Making of Jailer", features behind-the-scenes footage and interviews with the cast and crew.

Notes
------

* Jailer is Rajinikanth's 169th film.
* The film's script was written by Nelson Dilipkumar in collaboration with his brother, Vikram Dilipkumar.
* The film's title, Jailer, was chosen because it reflected the film's themes of justice and redemption.

References
----------

*None*

External links
---------------

article:
Chengiz is a 2018 Indian Bengali-language action thriller film directed by Rajesh Ganguly and starring Jeet, Susmita Chatterjee, and Shataf Figar. The film is a remake of the 2011 Tamil film Mouna Guru and follows the story of a young IPS officer who is wrongly accused of being involved in a murder case.

# Plot

Chengiz is based on the life of IPS officer Chengiz, who is known for his honesty and integrity. The film begins with Chengiz being posted as a DSP in a small town, where he is tasked with solving a murder case. However, in a twist of events, Chengiz is accused of being involved in the murder and is suspended from duty. With the help of his love interest, a journalist, Chengiz sets out to clear his name and uncover the truth behind the murder.

As Chengiz delves deeper into the case, he discovers a web of corruption and deceit that goes all the way to the top. He faces numerous challenges and obstacles, including a corrupt police force and a powerful politician who will stop at nothing to cover up the truth. Despite the odds against him, Chengiz refuses to give up and continues to fight for justice.

The film's climax features an intense showdown between Chengiz and the main antagonist, where Chengiz emerges victorious and clears his name. The film ends on a positive note, with Chengiz being reinstated as a DSP and continuing to fight for justice.

# Cast

* Jeet as Chengiz
* Susmita Chatterjee as Journalist
* Shataf Figar as Politician
* Kharaj Mukherjee as Corrupt Police Officer
* Kaushik Ganguly as Chengiz's Father
* Biswanath Basu as Journalist's Father

# Production

## Development and Pre-production

The film's director, Rajesh Ganguly, had previously worked with Jeet on several films and was known for his action-packed direction style. The film's script was written by Ganguly and his team, who drew inspiration from real-life events and police cases.

Pre-production work on the film began in 2017, with the cast and crew undergoing extensive training and preparation. Jeet, who played the lead role of Chengiz, underwent rigorous physical training to prepare for the film's action sequences.

## Casting

Casting for the film was a lengthy process, with the filmmakers taking several months to finalize the cast. Jeet was the first actor to be cast, with Susmita Chatterjee joining the cast soon after. The supporting cast, including Shataf Figar and Kharaj Mukherjee, were cast later.

The film's casting was widely praised, with critics noting that the cast brought a new level of energy and enthusiasm to the film.

# Soundtrack

The film's soundtrack was composed by Jeet Gannguli, who had previously worked on several Bengali films. The soundtrack features six tracks, including the popular song "Amar Ei Poth Chaoatei". The song was sung by Arijit Singh and became a huge hit, topping the charts for several weeks.

The film's background score was composed by Amit-Ujjwal, who had previously worked on several Bengali films. The background score was widely praised, with critics noting that it added to the film's tension and suspense.

# Marketing

Marketing for the film began several months before its release, with the filmmakers releasing several promotional posters and trailers. The film's trailer was released in 2018 and became a huge hit, generating millions of views on YouTube.

The film's promotional campaign was led by Jeet, who attended several press conferences and events to promote the film. The film's cast and crew also attended several promotional events, including a grand premiere at a popular multiplex in Kolkata.

# Release

## Theatrical

Chengiz was released on May 4, 2018, in West Bengal and other parts of India. The film was released in over 100 theaters, including several multiplexes and single-screen theaters.

The film's release was widely anticipated, with fans queuing up outside theaters to catch the first show. The film received a grand opening, with several shows selling out on the first day.

## Screenings and statistics

Chengiz was screened at several film festivals, including the Kolkata International Film Festival. The film was also screened at several multiplexes and single-screen theaters, including a grand premiere at a popular multiplex in Kolkata.

According to box office reports, Chengiz grossed over 10 crore on its opening weekend, making it one of the highest-grossing Bengali films of 2018.

# Reception

## Critical response

Chengiz received positive reviews from critics, who praised the film's action sequences, direction, and performances. The film's lead actor, Jeet, was widely praised for his performance, with critics noting that he brought a new level of energy and enthusiasm to the film.

The film's direction was also widely praised, with critics noting that Rajesh Ganguly had done a great job in handling the film's action sequences and suspense. The film's supporting cast, including Susmita Chatterjee and Shataf Figar, were also praised for their performances.

article:
October 2022 Conservative Party leadership election

The October 2022 Conservative Party leadership election was a leadership election held in the United Kingdom's Conservative Party to elect a new leader, following the resignation of Liz Truss as party leader and Prime Minister. The election was held between 24 and 28 October 2022.

#Background

##Boris Johnson premiership and scandals

Boris Johnson became the leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in July 2019, after winning a leadership election. During his premiership, Johnson faced several scandals, including the COVID-19 parties in Downing Street, the Owen Paterson lobbying scandal, and the Partygate scandal. The Partygate scandal, in particular, led to widespread criticism of Johnson's leadership and calls for his resignation.

##Leadership election to succeed Johnson

In July 2022, Johnson announced his resignation as Conservative Party leader and Prime Minister, following a series of resignations from his cabinet. A leadership election was held to succeed Johnson, which was won by Liz Truss. Truss defeated Rishi Sunak in the final round of the election, winning 57.4% of the vote.

##Liz Truss premiership and scandals

Liz Truss became the leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in September 2022. However, her premiership was short-lived and marked by several scandals, including the mini-budget controversy and the sacking of Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng. The mini-budget, which included large tax cuts and increased borrowing, was widely criticized and led to a significant decline in the value of the pound.

##Calls for Truss's resignation

Following the mini-budget controversy, there were widespread calls for Truss's resignation, including from within her own party. Several Conservative MPs publicly criticized Truss's leadership and called for her to step down. The opposition Labour Party also called for a vote of no confidence in Truss's government.

##Resignations and vote on fracking

In October 2022, several Conservative MPs resigned from their roles in protest at Truss's leadership. The government also faced a vote on fracking, which was widely opposed by Conservative MPs. The vote was seen as a test of Truss's authority, and the government's defeat was widely reported as a significant blow to her leadership.

##Liz Truss resigns

On 25 October 2022, Liz Truss announced her resignation as Conservative Party leader and Prime Minister, following a meeting with the party's 1922 Committee. Truss's resignation marked the end of her 49-day premiership, making her the shortest-serving Prime Minister in UK history.

#Campaign

The campaign for the October 2022 Conservative Party leadership election was marked by a series of hustings and debates between the candidates. The candidates set out their visions for the party and the country, and were questioned by Conservative MPs and party members.

#Election process

The election process was overseen by the Conservative Party's 1922 Committee. The committee set out the rules and timetable for the election, which was held between 24 and 28 October 2022. The election was held using a preferential voting system, in which Conservative MPs and party members voted for their preferred candidate.

#Candidates

##Declared

Several candidates declared their intention to stand in the leadership election, including Rishi Sunak, Penny Mordaunt, and Boris Johnson. Johnson's candidacy was seen as a significant development, given his recent resignation as Prime Minister.

##Withdrawn

Several candidates withdrew from the election, including Suella Braverman and Jeremy Hunt. Braverman and Hunt both endorsed Rishi Sunak's candidacy.

##Explored

Several candidates explored standing in the election, but ultimately decided not to. These included Michael Gove and Sajid Javid.

##Declined

Several candidates declined to stand in the election, including Dominic Raab and Priti Patel. Raab and Patel both endorsed Rishi Sunak's candidacy.

#Endorsements

Several Conservative MPs and party members endorsed candidates in the election. Rishi Sunak received endorsements from several senior Conservative MPs, including Michael Gove and Jeremy Hunt.

#Responses

The leadership election was widely reported in the media, with several newspapers and broadcasters covering the campaign and election. The opposition Labour Party also responded to the election, with leader Keir Starmer calling for a general election.

#Polling

Several polls were conducted during the leadership election, including polls of Conservative members, 2019 Conservative voters, and the general population.

##Conservative members

A poll of Conservative members found that Rishi Sunak was the preferred candidate, with 62% of the vote. Penny Mordaunt came second, with 21% of the vote.

##2019 Conservative voters

A poll of 2019 Conservative voters found that Rishi Sunak was the preferred candidate, with 55% of the vote. Penny Mordaunt came second, with 26% of the vote.

##General population

A poll of the general population found that Rishi Sunak was the preferred candidate, with 44% of the vote. Penny Mordaunt came second, with 24% of the vote.

article:
The Aesthetics of Resistance
==========================

The Aesthetics of Resistance is a novel by German author Peter Weiss, published in three volumes between 1975 and 1981. The novel is a sweeping narrative that combines elements of historical fiction, philosophical inquiry, and personal memoir to explore the intersections of art, politics, and resistance in 20th-century Europe.

Plot

Anti-Soviet resistance by the Ukrainian Insurgent Army

The Ukrainian Insurgent Army (UPA) was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary organization that engaged in anti-Soviet resistance during World War II and the post-war period. The UPA was formed in 1942 as a result of the merger of several Ukrainian nationalist groups, and it played a significant role in the struggle for Ukrainian independence from Soviet rule.

# Background

## Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists

The Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists (OUN) was a Ukrainian nationalist organization that was founded in 1929. The OUN was a radical organization that sought to establish an independent Ukrainian state through armed struggle. The organization was led by Stepan Bandera, who would later become a key figure in the Ukrainian nationalist movement.

## Outbreak of the war

In September 1939, Germany and the Soviet Union invaded Poland, and Ukraine was divided between the two powers. The OUN saw this as an opportunity to establish an independent Ukrainian state and began to mobilize its forces. However, the organization was soon suppressed by the Germans, who saw the OUN as a threat to their authority.

## Creation of OUN-B, pogroms, and anti-Soviet uprising

In 1940, a faction of the OUN, known as OUN-B, was formed under the leadership of Stepan Bandera. OUN-B was more radical than the original OUN and sought to establish an independent Ukrainian state through armed struggle. In June 1941, Germany launched a surprise attack on the Soviet Union, and OUN-B saw this as an opportunity to establish an independent Ukrainian state. The organization launched a series of pogroms against Jews and other minorities, and it also began to mobilize its forces for an anti-Soviet uprising.

## Creation of UPA, anti-German uprising, and extermination of Poles

In 1942, the Ukrainian Insurgent Army (UPA) was formed as a result of the merger of several Ukrainian nationalist groups, including OUN-B. The UPA was led by Roman Shukhevych, who would later become a key figure in the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The UPA launched a series of attacks against German forces, and it also began to exterminate Polish civilians in Volhynia and Galicia. This campaign of extermination, known as the Massacres of Poles in Volhynia and Eastern Galicia, resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of Polish civilians.

# Armed resistance during the war (1944–1945)

In the first half of 1944, the UPA launched a series of attacks against German forces in Volhynia and Podolia. The UPA also began to mobilize its forces for a larger anti-Soviet uprising. However, the UPA's efforts were ultimately unsuccessful, and the organization was forced to go underground.

## After German expulsion from Ukraine

### Battle of Zaliznytsia (28 April 1944)

On 28 April 1944, the UPA launched a surprise attack on the Soviet garrison in Zaliznytsia. The UPA was successful in capturing the town, but it was ultimately forced to retreat due to the arrival of Soviet reinforcements.

On 19 August 1944, the UPA launched a surprise attack on the Soviet garrison in Piryatin. The UPA was successful in capturing the town, and it held it for several days before being forced to retreat.

On 29-30 August 1944, the UPA launched a surprise attack on the Soviet garrison in Karov. The UPA was successful in capturing the town, and it held it for several days before being forced to retreat.

On 17 September 1944, the UPA launched a surprise attack on the Soviet garrison in Urman village. The UPA was successful in capturing the village, and it held it for several days before being forced to retreat.

On 30 September-1 October 1944, the UPA launched a surprise attack on the Soviet garrison in Univ. The UPA was successful in capturing the town, and it held it for several days before being forced to retreat.

On 28 October 1944, the UPA launched a surprise attack on the Soviet garrison in Leszczawa Górna. The UPA was successful in capturing the town, and it held it for several days before being forced to retreat.

In 1944, the UPA launched a campaign to impede the mobilization of Ukrainians to the Red Army. The UPA was successful in disrupting the mobilization efforts, and it also launched a series of attacks against Soviet recruitment centers.

In 1944, the UPA launched a series of attacks against Soviet cities in Ukraine. The UPA was successful in capturing several cities, including Lviv and Stanislaviv.

In 1945, the UPA launched a campaign to eliminate "Klim Savur", a Soviet agent who had infiltrated the UPA. The UPA was successful in eliminating "Klim Savur", and it also launched a series of attacks against Soviet agents who had infiltrated the organization.

In 1945, the UPA launched a series of attacks against Soviet cities in Ukraine. The UPA was successful in capturing several cities, including Kolomyya and Stryi.

After the war, the UPA maintained contacts with the special services of the West, including the CIA and MI6. The UPA received support from these agencies, and it also provided them with intelligence on Soviet activities in Ukraine.

In the late 1940s, the Soviet authorities launched a final campaign to suppress the UPA insurgency. The UPA was ultimately defeated, and its leaders were either killed or captured. The last UPA commander, Vasyl Kuk, was killed in 1954.

2022 German coup d'état plot

The 2022 German coup d'état plot refers to an alleged conspiracy to overthrow the German government, uncovered in December 2022. The plot involved a group of individuals with far-right and extremist ideologies, who aimed to seize power and establish an authoritarian regime.

# Members

The group behind the plot consisted of approximately 25 individuals, including former military personnel, police officers, and far-right activists. The alleged ringleader of the group was Heinrich XIII, Prince of Reuss, a 71-year-old member of the House of Reuss noble family. Other notable members included Rüdiger von Pescatore, a former paratrooper, and Birgit Malsack-Winkemann, a former Alternative for Germany (AfD) politician.

The group's membership was diverse, with individuals from various backgrounds and professions. However, they shared a common ideology and goal: to overthrow the current German government and establish a new order. The group's members were allegedly organized in a hierarchical structure, with Heinrich XIII at the top and various cells and subgroups below him.

# Ideology and aims

The group's ideology was rooted in far-right and extremist views, with a strong anti-government and anti-democratic sentiment. They believed that the current German government was corrupt and ineffective, and that a new authoritarian regime was necessary to restore order and stability.

The group's aims were to seize power and establish a new government, with Heinrich XIII as the leader. They planned to achieve this through a combination of violent and non-violent means, including armed insurrections, sabotage, and infiltration of key institutions.

The group's ideology was also characterized by a strong sense of nationalism and xenophobia, with a focus on protecting German culture and identity. They were opposed to immigration and multiculturalism, and believed that Germany should prioritize the interests of its native population.

# Investigations and arrests

The plot was uncovered by German authorities in December 2022, following a series of investigations and raids. The Federal Criminal Police Office (BKA) and the Federal Public Prosecutor's Office (GBA) had been monitoring the group's activities for several months, gathering evidence and intelligence on their plans.

On December 7, 2022, authorities launched a series of coordinated raids across Germany, arresting 25 individuals suspected of involvement in the plot. The raids were carried out by special police units, with support from the Federal Police and the Military Police.

The arrested individuals were taken into custody and charged with various crimes, including treason, sedition, and conspiracy to commit a terrorist act. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities continuing to gather evidence and build their case against the suspects.

# Reactions

## Domestic

The discovery of the plot sent shockwaves across Germany, with many politicians and citizens expressing outrage and concern. Chancellor Olaf Scholz condemned the plot, stating that "any attempt to undermine our democracy will be met with the full force of the law."

The AfD party, which had been linked to some of the suspects, distanced itself from the plot, stating that it did not condone violence or extremism. However, some critics accused the party of fostering a climate of hatred and intolerance that contributed to the plot.

The German media provided extensive coverage of the plot, with many outlets condemning the alleged conspirators and calling for greater action to combat far-right extremism.

## International

The international community also reacted with concern and condemnation. The European Union's Commissioner for Home Affairs, Ylva Johansson, stated that "the EU stands united against any form of extremism and terrorism."

The United States Embassy in Berlin issued a statement condemning the plot, saying that "the United States stands with Germany in its commitment to democracy and the rule of law."

Other countries, including France and the United Kingdom, also expressed their support for Germany and their condemnation of the plot.
